title: 104_s1856
content: The "Medicare Restoration Act of 1996" establishes the National Commission on Medicare Reform to address findings related to Medicare. The Congress acknowledges the importance of the Medicare program for senior citizens and individuals with disabilities. It recognizes the financial challenges facing the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the need for urgent action to restore the program's fiscal health. The National Commission on Medicare Reform is tasked with addressing these issues. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the financial condition of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. It must identify solvency threats, analyze potential solutions, and make recommendations to restore the trust funds' solvency and ensure sustainable growth. The Commission is responsible for reviewing the financial condition of the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. It must identify solvency threats, analyze potential solutions, and make recommendations to restore the trust funds' solvency and ensure sustainable growth. Additionally, the Commission is tasked with reviewing and analyzing other relevant matters as deemed appropriate. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Senate Majority Leader, and Speaker of the House. The Comptroller General advises on methodology. Members serve on the Commission for a specified term. The Commission consists of 15 members appointed for the life of the Commission. Meetings are held in the District of Columbia at the Chairperson's call. Ten members constitute a quorum. A Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are designated within 15 days of all members being appointed. Vacancies are filled within 30 days. Members receive no additional compensation. Each member of the Commission receives travel expenses and per diem in accordance with title 5, United States Code. No additional compensation is provided for their service on the Commission. SEC. 6. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Chairperson appoints a Director of the Commission who is paid at level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint staff with Commission approval, who are not bound by certain Civil Service Laws. The Director can also procure temporary services with Commission approval. The Commission may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission has access to resources, data, and information from various government branches. The General Services Administration will provide office space for the Commission's headquarters. The Commission's headquarters will be equipped with all necessary facilities for its proper functioning. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to conduct public hearings, delegate actions to its members or agents, accept gifts and use them for its work, and utilize the United States mails. The Commission has the authority to conduct public hearings, delegate actions, accept gifts, and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress by June 30, 1997. It will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide necessary funds for the Commission's operations.
